text:
Introduction
In the name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate.
All praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and from the consequences of our deeds. Whoever Allah guides, none can misguide; and whoever He misguides, none can guide. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and His Messenger.

{O you who believe, fear Allah as He should be feared, and do not die except as Muslims} (Aal 'Imran, 102).

{O mankind, fear your Lord who created you from a single soul, and created from it its mate, and spread from both many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed, Allah is ever watching over you} (An-Nisa, 1).

{O you who believe, fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice. He will correct your deeds for you and forgive your sins. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly attained a great success} (Al-Ahzab, 70–71).

To proceed: The best of speech is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad (peace be upon him). The worst of affairs are newly invented matters, and every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance leads to the Fire.

text: Then afterwards: Building a Muslim society cannot be achieved except by building the family, and the foundation for building a righteous Muslim family is the couple; they are the two building blocks upon which families are founded. It saddens the Muslim, especially in this time, to witness the disintegration of families and the destruction of many homes, to the point that it has become a phenomenon widely complained about and a widespread affliction. It has become incumbent upon reformers to treat it and mitigate its corruptions, but how? We hope to succeed in this treatise in contributing to the treatment of this phenomenon by explaining the purposes of marriage that the couple must understand, as well as parents and indeed the entire society. So we say, and we seek Allah's help: "The Purposes of Marriage": The purposes of marriage that most humans desire are three: Offspring, Service, and Pleasure. Before we begin explaining these purposes, we answer this question that some raise briefly, saying: "You encourage marriage and mention its virtues and good fruits, but when we got married, we found hardships, rights, duties, and responsibilities in which those pleasures dissolve!" We say: This is a valid question, and the answer is: This goes back to the difference in determination (Himmah) among men and women. Just as there is disparity among men, there is also disparity among women. Some see their happiness in abandoning responsibilities and neglecting

And some see happiness in fulfilling these rights, bearing these responsibilities, and rising to these burdens, finding in that their happiness and pleasure due to their high determination and elevated soul. The poet said: Were it not for hardship, all people would have prevailed ... Generosity impoverishes and boldness kills. To the explanation of these purposes, may Allah grant us and you success to understand and act upon them. First Purpose (Offspring): Allah Almighty said: {And We have already sent messengers before you and assigned to them wives and descendants} [Surah Ar-Ra'd: 38]. Abu Dawud narrated in his Sunan from the hadith of Ma'qil bin Yasar (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Marry the loving and fertile, for I will boast of your numbers before the nations." (1) Offspring is a valid demand and has worldly and hereafter benefits. Allah Almighty said: {Wealth and children are the adornment of the worldly life} [Surah Al-Kahf: 46]. And He said: {And We gave to David Solomon - an excellent servant, indeed he was one repeatedly turning back [to Allah]} [Surah Sad: 30]. And He said: {So We gave him good tidings of a forbearing boy} [Surah As-Saffat: 101]. (1) This purpose is shared between the spouses equally, and its benefits return to both spouses. Therefore, the spouses must know that each one of them has a favor over the other in bringing about offspring, and it is not permissible for either of them to see a favor for themselves in that which is not for the other. By understanding this reality, cooperation occurs between them to bear this responsibility, and thus carrying this heavy burden becomes lighter due to the couple's cooperation. This reality is what the noble female companion Khawlah bint Tha'labah (may Allah be pleased with her) understood when her husband declared Zihar upon her and she came complaining to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), saying: "O Messenger of Allah! I have children from him; if I keep them with me they will go hungry, and if I leave them to him they will be lost..." (2) So she understood (may Allah be pleased with her) that raising children and caring for them is not accomplished except by the cooperation of the spouses, and that without that - due to separation or discord - harm befalls the children through hunger and loss. text: and prays for her, so her service becomes a source of joy, happiness, pride, and glory. So women should realize this and appreciate it duly. Knowing this truth and acting upon it out of conviction and satisfaction drives each of them to do what they must without complaint or feeling of injustice or oppression, because each knows that just as they have a duty they must perform, the other also has a duty like theirs, even if the types differ. What is obligatory on one is a right for the other, and consequently, the arrogance and reminding of favors which causes the scattering and separation of families ceases. Allah Almighty said: {And due to the wives is similar to what is expected of them, according to what is reasonable} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 228]. Third Purpose: (Pleasure) It is the broadest of these purposes and the most beneficial if performed well, and the most harmful if neglected. Pleasure does not only mean the bed, but it is broader than that, as it includes all aspects of life. It is required from both spouses, with some difference in what is obligatory on each of them, according to what the nature of each requires. When the couple lives as one soul, one rejoicing in the other's joy, grieving for their grief, caring for their concern, and each striving for the other's pleasure, then a happy and blissful life is guaranteed for them. But let it be known that this will not be upright for them except by resolving to maintain this close bond between them until they meet in the Gardens of Bliss (1).

text: It was mentioned previously that the third purpose of marriage in its broader sense is the most extensive of these purposes, the most beneficial if performed well, and the most harmful if neglected. Among its effects is that it serves other purposes positively and negatively. It is required from both spouses, although the wife is more deserving of it and more capable of it due to the attractive feminine composition and sweet, beautiful signals Allah created her with. There is nothing in the world more delightful, better, or more pleasurable than a righteous woman. All pleasures of life reverse during fluctuations, but a righteous woman remains so; indeed, happiness with her increases with the intensification of conditions and hardships of life. Through this, we understand his saying (peace and blessings be upon him) in what Muslim narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The world is enjoyment, and the best enjoyment of the world is a righteous woman." (1) We will cite below some Quranic verses and noble Prophetic hadiths that include the application of this purpose to help understand it. Let it be known that in this chapter we do not intend to explain rights and duties, but rather to clarify the areas of pleasure each spouse gives to the other concerning beautiful morals and high manners, and that it encompasses all aspects of life. 1 - Allah Almighty said: {They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 187]. Among the means of making each other happy is to be

These wives of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and may Allah be pleased with them, when they were given the choice between the world and the Hereafter and chose Allah and His Messenger, their reward was what the Almighty informed of by His saying: {Not lawful to you, [O Muhammad], are [any additional] women after [this], nor [is it] for you to exchange them for [other] wives, even if their beauty were to please you, except what your right hand possesses} [Surah Al-Ahzab: 52]. 6 - One of the best and finest things a husband enjoys is that his wife guards her gaze, for if she is like that, she is more guarding of what is beyond that. Allah Almighty said: {And tell the believing women to reduce [some] of their vision} [Surah An-Nur: 31]. Allah described the women of Paradise saying: {In them are women limiting [their] glances} [Surah Ar-Rahman: 56]. Similarly, the wife finds happiness and comfort when she sees her husband guarding his gaze in compliance with His Almighty saying: {Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision} [Surah An-Nur: 30], knowing that if he guards his gaze, he is more guarding of what is beyond that. 7 - Among the greatest things the couple enjoys is that each sees in the other this beautiful trait which is a branch of faith, the trait of modesty (Haya'). For if modesty exists, no blameworthy morals or sick attributes can rise with it. Therefore, he (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Modesty is all good." text: Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: "As if there was no woman in the world except Khadijah." (1) She (may Allah be pleased with her) attained through her good companionship what no one else attained. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "Gabriel came to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah! This is Khadijah who has come to you with a vessel containing condiment, or food, or drink. When she comes to you, convey to her the greeting of peace from her Lord and from me, and give her the glad tidings of a house in Paradise made of Qasab (hollow pearl), wherein there will be no noise (sakhab) and no toil (nasab)." (2) Qasab is hollow pearl, spacious like a lofty palace. Sakhab is the mixing of voices. Nasab is fatigue. Al-Suhayli said: He gave her glad tidings of a house in Paradise made of Qasab - meaning pearl Qasab - because she won the Qasab (prize) of precedence to faith; wherein there is no noise and no toil, because she never raised her voice over the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and never wearied him a single day of time, so she never shouted at him a day nor hurt him ever (3). These are some of her stances (may Allah be pleased with her and please her), with which we concluded this chapter, and musk is the best conclusion. * * *
foot_note:
1. Sahih Al-Bukhari number (3818) from the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). 
2. Sahih Al-Bukhari number (3820), and Sahih Muslim number (2432). 
3. Al-Bidaya wa'l-Nihaya by Ibn Kathir (may Allah have mercy on him) (4/317).

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: A Section from it: 16 - Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him): That a man came to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah? Exhaustion has afflicted me. So he sent to his wives, and they said: We have nothing but water. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Who will host or entertain this man [tonight, may Allah have mercy on him]?" A man from the Ansar said: I will [O Messenger of Allah!]. So he went with him to his wife and said: "Honor the guest of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) [do not save anything]." She said: "[By Allah] We have nothing but my children's sustenance." He said: "Prepare your food, light your lamp, and put your children to sleep if they want dinner. [And come, extinguish the lamp, and we will fold our stomachs (go hungry) tonight]." So she prepared her food, lit her lamp, and put her children to sleep. Then she got up as if she was fixing her lamp and extinguished it. They made him think they were eating, and they spent the night hungry. When morning came, he went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) who said: "Allah laughed - or wondered - last night at your action." So Allah revealed: {And they give preference over themselves, even though they are in privation. And whoever is protected from the stinginess of his soul - it is those who will be the successful} [Surah Al-Hashr: 9] (1). Islam has magnified the status of women and praised their noble stances, and revealed concerning them a Quran recited until the Day of Resurrection. So woe, then woe to those who seek to show Islam as other than that.
foot_note: 1. Mukhtasar Sahih Al-Bukhari by Sheikh Al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him) number 1614, and Muslim narrated it under number 2054 with a different wording.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: To explain the reason for citing this story, contemplate the following points: (a) This guest is not like any other guest, but a special guest, for he is the guest of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). (b) This noble Companion (may Allah be pleased with him) took this guest with him to his house to host him, seeking thereby the pleasure of Allah Almighty and the pleasure of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), hoping that the Prophet's supplication would reach him, and to bring joy to himself as he is from a people who love honoring guests. (c) He informed his wife that this guest is a special guest so she could share in the reward, virtue, and praise (1), and he did not say to her: This does not concern you, do what I order you. (d) The Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him) did not find any food in his house except what was enough for his children. In this situation where embarrassment reached its peak, he found himself in need of someone to help him and stand with him to attain these virtues, and he found her. Who could it be? (e) It is his righteous, generous, wise, intelligent, patient, loyal wife. (f) If she had said to her husband: Two rights have combined upon you: the right of the guest and the right of the family, and you must prioritize the more worthy of them, which is here the right of the family, his chest would have tightened, and his embarrassment would have become great. But she (may Allah be pleased with her) did not say that due to the generosity of her soul and the goodness of her companionship. (g) Out of the generosity of her soul and good companionship, she intended and resolved to prefer others over herself, spending the night with an empty stomach so that her husband could attain those virtues and great honor, and to beautify him before the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and his guest.
foot_note: 1. Hamd: is commendation and praise.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: She did not say: I have nothing but what suffices me, but rather ignored herself and said: I have nothing but the children's dinner. (h) Out of her intelligence and fear that her action might not be correct in prioritizing the guest's right over the children's right, she said that to her husband so they could share in the decision and bear its consequences with him. She could have evaded and said to her husband: This is what is available, feed whomever you wish, and absolved herself of responsibility. But she (may Allah be pleased with her) did not do that due to the generosity of her soul and good companionship. What an excellent righteous role model. (i) One of the greatest things a person faces is the jurisprudence of priorities and prioritizing duties and rights over one another when they conflict. In this story is an example to follow, and the successful one is whom Allah grants success. Whoever Allah wants good for, He gives him understanding of the religion. (j) In this story, the theoretical idea was shared between the spouses, but the one who executed it, bore its burdens, and raised its banner was the blessed wife. Thus, she deserved the immortalization of her mention and that her Lord wondered at her deed and her husband's deed. (k) They (may Allah be pleased with them both) did not limit themselves in honoring the guest of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to just preparing his dinner, but added to that bringing joy to him. That was by showing that honoring him did not cause them hardship and that what they presented to him was surplus to their need, so they extinguished the lamp and made him think they were eating. This is what was facilitated to explain regarding our topic, and the story has other benefits, the most prominent of which we mention briefly:
foot_note: None

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: 1 - In this story is a clarification of his status (peace and blessings be upon him) and his great rank with his Lord. For when these two Companions hosted his guest and fulfilled the right due upon him, Allah immortalized their good mention in verses recited until the Day of Resurrection. So imagine how great the status of one who undertakes his call, spreads his Sunnah, and defends his religion would be?! 2 - In it: What he (peace and blessings be upon him) was upon of straitened living and lack of means by his own choice, for if he wished it would have been otherwise, but he (peace and blessings be upon him) preferred the Enduring over the Perishing and the Hereafter over the First, and chose to be a Servant Messenger. 3 - In it: The virtue of the wives of the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him), and their great patience and their choice of Allah and His Messenger over the worldly life and its adornment. 4 - In it: That among the duties and obligations are those of communal obligation (Fard Kifayah), for the right of this guest fell from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) by the performance of these two Companions. 5 - In it: That a man asking one of his Muslim brothers to undertake a right obligatory upon him that he cannot fulfill is not blameworthy asking. 6 - In it: That honoring a guest is not only by feeding food, but includes other things like welcoming him, entertaining him with conversation, and others in which people differ from one society to another. The poet said: The fire if lit is the text of generosity ... And the other text is what is available of food. 7 - In it: That the host should show his guest what reassures the guest that it did not cause him hardship, even if the matter is contrary to that. 8 - In it: That altruism (Ithar) is among the best morals and virtues of deeds, and it is,
foot_note: None

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: with poverty, greater and more majestic. 9 - In it: That a person's soul may aspire to acquire virtues, but he may need a helper in some of them. If he finds one, let him hold on to them and not neglect them, for their existence is rare. 10 - In it: That a person showing actions contrary to reality is not considered blameworthy lying if it is for an interest requiring it. 11 - In it: The virtue of patience and its great reward. Their patience with hunger despite their ability to be full, their patience with the pain squeezing their hearts when seeing their children spending the night hungry, indeed they are the ones putting them to sleep, and the wife's patience with her husband who brought her all these burdens. All this while they did not know that this deed of theirs would be a reason for immortalizing their mention in the best of Books and on the tongue of the best of Messengers. And what is with Allah is better and more enduring. 12 - In it: Affirmation of two attributes of Allah Almighty: Wonder and Laughter. * * *
foot_note: None

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: A Section from it: 17 - Among the beauties of marital life is that the couple exchanges beneficial conversations and useful stories. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: "The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), when he prayed the two Rak'ahs of Fajr, if I was awake he would talk to me, otherwise he would lie down." (1) 18 - And here is the Mother of Believers Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) narrating to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) a strange news about women's evaluation of their husbands, and the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) listens to her and comments on her speech. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from the hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: Eleven women sat and promised and covenanted that they would not conceal anything of the news of their husbands. The first said: My husband is flesh of a lean (2) camel on top of a mountain; it is not easy so it can be climbed, nor fat so it can be moved (3).
foot_note:
1. Sahih Al-Bukhari number (1161), and Sahih Muslim number (743) and the wording is his. 
2. i.e., like camel meat in badness, not like sheep meat. It is intended to exaggerate the lack of benefit, disinterest in it, and aversion of nature to it. 
3. It is intended to exaggerate his arrogance and bad character, so he cannot be reached except with extreme difficulty, and he does not benefit his wife in companionship or otherwise despite being disliked and bad. The meaning of 'nor moved' is that people do not move it to their homes to eat it after enduring the fatigue and hardship of reaching it, but rather turn away from it due to its badness. In summary, she described him as miserly, bad, arrogant towards his family, and ill-tempered.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: The second said: My husband, I do not spread (1) his news, I fear I will not leave him (2). If I mention him, I mention his Ujar and Bujar (3). The third said: My husband is the 'Ashannaq (4). If I speak, I get divorced (5). If I stay silent, I get suspended (6). The fourth said: My husband is like the night of Tihama (7). Neither heat nor cold (8). Neither fear nor boredom. The fifth said: My husband, if he enters, becomes a leopard (9). If he goes out, he becomes a lion (10). And he does not ask
foot_note:
1. i.e., I do not reveal and broadcast it. 
2. i.e., she fears if she mentions him he will divorce her. I say: Rather the correct view is that the pronoun refers to the news, meaning if I start the news I fear I won't finish it due to its abundance. Comment of Sheikh Nasir al-Din al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him). 
3. With Damma on the first and Fatha on the second, meaning all his faults, visible and hidden. Ujar: plural of 'ujrah, which is a swelling in the neck veins. Bujar: plural of bujrah: the navel. She means: I do not delve into mentioning his news, for I fear from mentioning it discord, separation, and loss of children and family. 
4. With Fatha on 'Ayn and Shin, and Nun open and stressed. It is the tall one whose height is disliked, slender, and ill-tempered. 
5. i.e., if I speak of his faults in detail, he divorces me for his bad temper, and I do not like divorce for the sake of my children from him, or for my need of him. 
6. i.e., and if I stay silent about his faults, he makes me suspended, which is the woman who is neither married to a benefiting husband nor divorced expecting to marry. 
7. In perfect moderation, lack of harm, and ease of his affair. Tihama: Mecca and its surroundings. 
8. A metaphor for lack of harm due to his noble character and the establishment of all kinds of pleasure in his company. 
9. i.e., if he enters upon her, he leaps like a leopard for intercourse. Or 'Fahida' man: slept a lot like a leopard. 
10. And if he goes out from her or mixes with people, he acts like a lion.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: about what he promised (1). The sixth said: My husband, if he eats, he eats excessively (2). If he drinks, he drinks up everything (3). If he lies down, he wraps himself up (4). And he does not insert his palm to know the grief (5). The seventh said: My husband is Ghayaya' (6) or 'Ayaya' Tabaqa'. Every disease is his disease (7). He injures you or breaks you or combines both for you. The eighth said: My husband, the scent is the scent of Zarnab (8). And the touch is the touch of a rabbit (9). The ninth said: My husband is of high pillar, long sword-belt, great ashes, close of
foot_note:
1. i.e., he does not ask about what he knew in his house of food and drink etc. out of generosity. So she described him as generous in nature, good in companionship, gentle in his house, strong and brave among his enemies, not checking what went of his wealth and belongings, and not asking about it due to the honor of his soul and generosity of his heart. 
2. i.e., ate a lot, and mixed types of food. 
3. i.e., drank the 'shufafah' which is the rest of the water at the bottom, i.e., he leaves nothing in the vessel. 
4. i.e., if he lies on his side, he wraps himself in his clothes and covers himself with a quilt alone in a corner by himself and does not touch her, so there is no benefit in him for his wife. 
5. i.e., he does not put his hand under her clothes to know her grief and sadness, so he has no compassion for her. 
6. i.e., incapable of managing his affairs due to 'Ay' (inability), or it is said he is impotent. Ghayaya': possessor of Ghayy which is error or disappointment. Tabaqa': stupid, or one whose affairs are closed upon him, or incapable of intercourse or speech. 
7. i.e., all people's faults gathered in him. (Injures you ...) i.e., either breaks his wives' heads, or breaks a limb of their limbs, or combines both for them. 
8. i.e., my husband's touch is like the touch of a rabbit in softness and smoothness. 
9. With Fatha on Zay, a type of plant with a good scent. Meaning she describes him with good character, noble companionship, and gentleness like the softness of a rabbit's touch, and compared the scent of his body or clothes to the scent of perfume. It may mean the goodness of praise for him spreading among people.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: house to the club (Nad) (1). The tenth said: My husband is Malik (2). And what is Malik? Malik is better than that. He has camels of many kneeling places (3), few pastures (4). If they hear the sound of the Mizhar (lute), they become certain they are perishing (5). The eleventh said: My husband is Abu Zar' (6). And what is Abu Zar'? He made my ears swing (7) with jewelry (8). And filled my upper arms with fat (9). And pleased me so I became pleased with myself (10).
foot_note:
1. 'Imad (Pillar) originally means pillars upon which houses stand; she used it metaphorically for his high status and noble lineage. Nijad with Kasra on Nun: sword suspenders. She used it metaphorically for tall stature, indicating he is a sword owner, thus pointing to his bravery. Ashes is a metaphor for abundant generosity necessitating frequent hospitality, necessitating much ash and continuous fire burning. Nad is originally Nadi, the Ya was dropped for rhyming. Nadi: The place where the notables of the people gather for consultation and conversation. This is the way of the generous; they place their houses near the club to expose themselves to those who would be their guests. 
2. i.e., his name is Malik. Better than that: i.e., better than what I will say about him, hinting he is above description in generosity and magnanimity. 
3. Plural of Mabrak, place of camels kneeling. 
4. i.e., his camels are many when kneeling, so if they go to pasture they are few because many of them are in their kneeling places for guests, or he leaves them beside the house so if guests descend upon him they are present. 
5. i.e., if the camels hear the sound of the Oud being played, they become certain they will be slaughtered for guests due to his generosity. 
6. She nicknamed him that for his abundant crops (Zar'), and it is possible she nicknamed him that out of optimism for many children, Zar' meaning child. 
7. Weight of 'Aqama', from Naws which is movement while hanging. 
8. Meaning he moved her ears due to what he adorned them with. 
9. Made me fat. 
10. Meaning: He made me happy so my soul rejoiced.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: He found me among people of few sheep in Shiqq (1). So he placed me among people of neighing, groaning, threshing, and purifying (2). With him I speak and am not criticized (3). I sleep and wake up in the morning (4). I drink and quench my thirst (5). Mother of Abu Zar', what is the mother of Abu Zar'? (6): Her sacks are heavy (7). And her house is spacious (8). Son of Abu Zar', what is the son of Abu Zar'? (9): His sleeping place is like a drawn palm-stick (10). And satiates him
foot_note:
1. Diminutive for fewness, i.e., people of few sheep. Shiqq with Fatha and Kasra, possibly a place name or meaning hardship, as in His saying: {Bi-shiqqi al-anfus} [Surah An-Nahl: 7]. Meaning: He found me among people of few sheep, so they were in effort, hardship, and [difficult] living. 
2. i.e., he carried me to people of horses with neighing, camels with groaning. Neighing: sound of horses. Groaning: sound of camels. And cows threshing the crop in its threshing floor to extract grain from the ear. Munaqqin with Damma on Mim, Fatha on Nun, and stressed Qaf: one who purifies the grain and cleans it from straw etc. after threshing with a sieve etc. So they are owners of crops and clean grain. The meaning of all this: She was among people of scarcity and hardship, so he moved her to people of wealth and abundance, being owners of horses, camels, etc. 
3. i.e., I speak with him with any speech and he does not attribute ugliness to me due to my honor with him and my good speech to him. 
4. i.e., I sleep and enter the morning, and he is gentle with me and does not wake me for his service or work, because I am beloved to him and sufficed by servants who serve him and me. 
5. i.e., I quench my thirst and leave water due to its abundance with him, despite its scarcity with others. Meaning: She did not suffer from him, neither regarding sleeping nor drinking. I say: In Al-Nihayah: "She meant she drinks until she is quenched and raises her head. It is said: Qamaha the camel Yaqmahu if it raises its head from water after quenching thirst. It is also narrated with Nun." 
6. She wanted to praise her husband's mother after praising her husband. 
7. i.e., her sacks and food containers are huge, heavy, numerous. 'Ukum plural of 'Ikm which is the sack if it contains goods. Radah: with Fatha on Ra': huge, heavy, numerous. 
8. With Fatha on Fa', i.e., wide. The spaciousness of the house indicates the abundance of wealth. 
9. She moved to praising the son of Abu Zar'. 
10. i.e., his sleeping place is like Masall: with Fatha on first and second, meaning drawn. Shatbah: with Fatha on Shin and Sukun on Ta', which is what is stripped or split from palm branches, i.e., the frond. Meaning the place of his lying, which is the side, is like a strip drawn from the branch in thinness; he is light in flesh, slender in waist like the strip drawn from its peel.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: the leg of a young goat (1). Daughter of Abu Zar', what is the daughter of Abu Zar'? Obedient to her father and obedient to her mother (2). Filling her clothes (3). And rage of her neighbor (4). Maid of Abu Zar', what is the maid (5) of Abu Zar'? She does not spread our talk spreading (6). Nor does she waste our provision wasting (7). Nor does she fill our house with nests (8). She said: Abu Zar' went out (9) while the milk skins were being churned (10). He met a woman with two children
foot_note:
1. With Damma on Ta because it is from satisfaction. Al-Jafrah with Fatha on Jim and Sukun on Fa is the female kid goat. The meaning is that he is slender, slim, with little flesh consistently, which is the way of the noble. 
2. i.e., she is obedient to her father and mother with utmost obedience. 
3. i.e., filling her clothes due to her hugeness and fatness, which is praiseworthy in women. 
4. Meaning her co-wife; she enrages her co-wife due to her jealousy of her because of her excessive beauty. 
5. i.e., his servant. 
6. Meaning she does not spread our words we speak among ourselves, due to her religiousness. 
7. i.e., she does not transport our food transporting due to her trustworthiness and maintenance. Tunaqqith with Fatha on Ta, Damma on Qaf, and Nun is silent [Note: text says Damma on Qaf but usually Tashdid]. Meaning: does not transport. Mirah: with Kasra on Mim: Food. 
8. i.e., she does not make our house full of garbage and sweepings until it becomes like a bird's nest, but fixes and cleans it due to her cleverness. 
9. Went out for a journey one day. 
10. i.e., while the Awtab (milk skins, plural of Watb) were being churned (Tumkhad, passive voice) to extract butter from milk. Meaning he went out during the time of abundant milk, which is the time Arabs go out for trade.

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: like two leopards (1), playing under her waist with two pomegranates (2). So he divorced me and married her. I married after him a noble man (3). He rode a tireless horse (4). And took a linear spear (5). And brought back (*) to me many livestock (6). And gave me a pair of every scenting animal (7). He said: Eat, Umm Zar', and provide for your family (8). But if I gathered everything he gave me, it would not reach the smallest vessel of Abu Zar'. Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to me: "I was to you like Abu Zar' to Umm Zar'." (9) (10). Ibn Hajar (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "It is as if he (peace and blessings be upon him) said that to comfort her and reassure her heart and to dispel the illusion of generalizing the similarity to all of Abu Zar's conditions, since there was nothing in him that women dislike except that (divorce), and this was explicitly stated. She answered him with an answer
foot_note:
1. i.e., like them in leaping, playing, and speed of movement. 
2. i.e., having two small breasts like pomegranates, so her two children play with her breasts resembling pomegranates. 
3. i.e., from the nobles and elites. 
4. i.e., a horse that persists in its run without fatigue. 
5. Which is the spear attributed to Al-Khatt, a village on the coast of the sea of Oman where spears are made. (*) I say: The original is Rah (went/rested), which is a mistake contrary to what is in the Two Sahihs and Al-Nihayah [Correct word is 'Araha' meaning brought back livestock in the evening]. 
6. i.e., he made enter upon me at the time of Rawah (afternoon), or put into the pen (Murah). An-Na'am: Camels, sheep, cows. Thariyya: from Tharwa meaning abundant wealth. 
7. Gave her from every animal going to his house at the time of Rawah a pair, two by two. 
8. i.e., the husband who married her after Abu Zar' said: Eat whatever you wish and give to your relatives. 
9. Sahih Al-Bukhari number (5189), and Sahih Muslim number (2448) and the wording is his. 
10. The hadith in full with meanings of words is quoted from Mukhtasar Al-Shama'il Al-Muhammadiyyah edited by Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him), pp. (134-142).

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: like hers in virtue and knowledge" (1). In Al-Tabarani's narration he said: "O Aisha, I was to you like Abu Zar' to Umm Zar', except that Abu Zar' divorced, and I do not divorce." (2) In another narration: I said: "O Messenger of Allah, you are better to me than Abu Zar' to Umm Zar'." (3) 19 - It is often said: Behind every great man is a woman. Is this saying correct? And how so? Answer: Look at this story. The Wisest of Arab Women: Al-Harith bin Awf said one day to Kharijah bin Sinan Al-Murri: Do you think I would propose to anyone and he would reject me? He said to him: Yes! He said: Who is that? He said: Aws bin Harithah bin Lam Al-Ta'i. So Al-Harith said to his servant: Let us travel. So he did, and they rode until they came to Aws bin Harithah bin Lam Al-Ta'i and found him in the courtyard of his house. When he saw Al-Harith bin Awf, he said: Welcome, O Harith. He said: And you. He said: What brought you? He said: I came to you as a suitor. He said: You are not there (i.e., not acceptable). So he turned away and did not speak to him. Aws entered upon his wife angry, and she was from 'Abs. She said: Who is the man standing by you who did not stay long, and whom you did not speak to? He said: That is the master of the Arabs, Al-Harith bin Awf. She said: So why didn't you ask him to dismount? He said: He acted foolishly! She said:
foot_note:
1. Fath Al-Bari (9/275). 
2. Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir by Al-Tabarani (23/173) number (270), and authenticated by Sheikh Al-Albani (may Allah have mercy on him) as in Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir number 141. 
3. Sunan Al-Nasa'i Al-Kubra (9138).

book_title: Happiness and Success in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage
text: How? He said: He came to me proposing! She said: Do you want to marry off your daughters? He said: Yes. She said: If you don't marry off to the master of the Arabs, then to whom? He said: It has happened. She said: Then rectify what came from you. He said: By what? She said: Catch up to him and bring him back. He said: How, when it has already escaped me? She said: Say to him: You met me while I was angry about a matter in which you did not present a word beforehand, so I had no answer for it except what you heard. Return, and you shall have from me whatever you like. For he will do so. So he rode after them. Kharijah bin Sinan said: By Allah, I was traveling with Al-Harith when I turned and saw Aws. So I turned to Al-Harith - who was not speaking to me out of grief - and said: Aws bin Harithah is following us. He said: What should we do with him? Continue. When he saw we were not stopping for him, he shouted: Harith, wait for me a moment. So I spoke to him with those words, and he returned happy. Aws entered his home and said to his wife: Call so-and-so for me - meaning his eldest daughter. She came to him. He said: O daughter, this is Al-Harith bin Awf, a master of the masters of the Arabs. He came to me proposing and I wanted to marry you to him, what do you say? She said: Do not do it. For I am a woman with ugliness in my face, and some sharpness - fault - in my character. I am not his cousin so he would respect my kinship, and he is not your neighbor in the land so he would be shy of you. I am not safe if he sees from me what he dislikes that he will divorce me. He said the same to the middle one and she answered like the eldest... So he called the youngest and presented the matter to her. She said: It is up to you. He said: I presented that to your two sisters and they refused. She said - and he did not mention their words to her -: But I, by Allah, am beautiful of face, skilled of hand, noble of character, of noble father. If he divorces me, Allah will not replace him with good. He said: May Allah bless you. Then he went out to Al-Harith and said: I marry you, O Harith, to my daughter Buhaysah bint Aws. He said: I accept. He ordered her mother to prepare her and fix her affairs, then ordered a tent to be set up for them. Then he sent her to him... The narrator Kharijah bin Sinan said: When Buhaysah was brought in to him, he stayed a little while then came out. I said: Are you done with your affair? He said: No, by Allah. Kharijah bin Sinan said: How? He said: When I entered upon her she said: Stop, in the presence of my father
foot_note: None

text: I returned one day from a funeral purified, and passed by a tent. There was an old woman with a young girl (Ra'ud) (1). I asked for water. She said: Which is more pleasing to you, milk or water? I said: Milk is more pleasing to me. She said: O daughter, give him milk to drink for I think he is a stranger. She gave me drink. When I drank I said: Who is this girl? She said: This is Zaynab bint Hudayr, one of the women of Banu Tamim, then from Banu Hanzalah, then from Banu Tuhayya. I said: Will you marry her to me? She said: Yes, if you are compatible. So I returned to my house, refrained from the midday nap. When I prayed Zuhr, I sent for my trustworthy brothers Masruq bin Al-Ajda' and Al-Aswad bin Yazid. I prayed Asr then went to her uncle who was in his mosque. When he saw me he moved aside for me from his seat. I said: You are more deserving of your seat and we are seekers of a need. He said: Welcome O Abu Umayyah, what is your need? I said: I mentioned Zaynab, your brother's daughter. He said: By Allah, she has no dislike for you, and you are not falling short of her. He said: And I spoke and he married me. Then I left. I didn't reach my house until I regretted and said to myself: What have I done? I thought to send her divorce. Then I said: I will not combine two foolishnesses, but I will join her to me. If I see what I like I praise Allah, and if it is the other I divorce her. So I sent her dowry and honor. When she was brought to me and the women stood away from her, I said: O you, it is from the Sunnah that if a woman is brought to her husband, they pray two Rak'ahs behind him and ask Allah Almighty for blessing. So I stood praying and she was behind me. When I finished I returned to my place and extended my hand. She said: Gently. I said: One of them, by the Lord of the Kaaba. She said: Praise be to Allah and blessings of Allah upon our master Muhammad and his family. Afterwards, I am a stranger woman, and by Allah I have not ridden a mount more difficult for me than this. You are a man whose character I do not know, so tell me what you like and what you dislike so I avoid it. I say this saying of mine and ask Allah forgiveness for me and you. He said: So I said: Praise be to Allah and blessings of Allah upon Muhammad and his family. Afterwards, you have come

text: to the family of your husband's house as master of their men, and you, God willing, are mistress of their women, whether they like this or hate it. She said: Tell me about your in-laws, do you like them to visit you? I said: I am a judge, so I hate that they bore me and I hate that they cut me off. He said: So I stayed with her for a year, and every day I was more pleased with her than the day that passed. I returned one day from the session of judgment and found an old woman ordering and forbidding in my house. I said: Who is this, O Zaynab? She said: This is your mother-in-law, this is my mother. I said: How are you, O you? She said: How are you O Abu Umayyah, and how do you find your wife? I said: All good. She said: A woman is never worse in character than in two situations: if she gives birth to a boy, and if she gains favor with her husband. So if you doubt your wife, then the whip. I said: I bear witness that she is your daughter; you have sufficed me the training and perfected the discipline. She used to come to me once every year and advise me with this advice then leave. I stayed with her for twenty years; I never got angry with her a single day or night except one day, and I was unjust to her. That is, I prayed the two Rak'ahs of Fajr and saw a scorpion. I hurried to kill it but covered it with a vessel and said: O Zaynab, beware the vessel. I went out to prayer. She hurried to the vessel and moved it, so the scorpion stung her. If you saw me, O Sha'bi, sucking her finger and reciting Al-Mu'awwidhatayn over her. I had a neighbor called Qais bin Jarir, who used to beat his wife constantly. So upon that I used to say: I saw men beating their women ... May my right hand be paralyzed when I beat Zaynab. Zaynab is a sun and women are stars ... When she rises she leaves none of them a star. And I am the one who says: If Zaynab's family visited her ... I gathered and honored her visitors. And if she visited them I visited her ... Even if I had no desire for her house (1).

text: Section: On Explaining Some Landmarks That Aid in Understanding the Purposes of Marriage and Ways to Achieve Them. Allah Almighty said: {It is He who created you from one soul and created from it its mate that he might dwell in security with her} [Surah Al-A'raf: 189]. And He said: {And of His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy} [Surah Ar-Rum: 21]. Let us contemplate His saying: {that he might dwell in security with her}, and His saying: {that you may find tranquility in them}. What is this dwelling (Sakan)? How is the tranquility? What are its effects on the life of the couple? And what is the duty to do? It is said in Al-Qamus: Sakan is everything one dwells in and finds tranquility in, of family and others (1). In these two noble verses, Allah Almighty specified the wife with that, making her the dwelling for her husband. Tranquility is reassurance and comfort. This great word has included wide meanings encompassing almost all aspects of life. Look at the state of normal people when they are outside their dwellings and what constraint is required of them in controlling speech, dress, movement, and stillness. Then look at them

text: when they return to their dwellings, how that constraint disappears from them in their eating, drinking, sleeping, and other things due to the reassurance and relaxation they obtain. Likewise, the wife is the dwelling for her husband. When she is like that, she is acting according to the wisdom of the Creator - Exalted be He - and He has created her prepared for that. So let her praise Allah and increase in thanking Him. Allah Almighty said: {It has been made lawful for you the night preceding fasting to go to your wives [for sexual relations]. They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 187]. In His saying: {They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them} is a great meaning the couple must pay attention to and act according to, and it is a mutual right between them. The explanation of that is that clothing has three great purposes: First: Covering what one is shy to reveal. Second: Protection from heat, cold, and the like. Third: Beautification. Allah Almighty said: {O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts and as adornment. But the clothing of righteousness - that is best. That is from the signs of Allah that perhaps they will remember} [Surah Al-A'raf: 26]. And 'Riyash' (adornment/feathers) is what one beautifies oneself with in addition to covering private parts and protection from harms. If we understand this, let us know that each of the spouses needs these three from the other. The greatest of them: 1 - Covering: The spouses must cover each other and not reveal

text: about him what harms him to be revealed, nor spread a secret of his. 2 - To protect him with themselves from harms that hurt him, like clothing protects from heat and cold. 3 - Then to ascend after that so that each of them is like adornment for the other, beautifying him and showing his virtues. And Allah Almighty said: {But the men have a degree over them} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 228]. Under this noble sentence fall great meanings and majestic wisdoms, except that benefiting from them is based on believing in them, submitting to them, and correct understanding of what they indicate. Here is the explanation: 1 - It must be known that the Creator of creation - Exalted be He - has profound wisdom in His creation and command. He composed men with a constitution fitting what they were tasked with, and composed women with a constitution fitting what they were created for. So whoever is guided to what they were created for succeeds in both abodes and attains both happinesses. And whoever is not guided, it is evidence of the reversion of their nature and consequently corruption of thought and action. 2 - Allah explained in another verse what was summarized in this verse, saying: {Men are in charge of women by [right of] what Allah has given one over the other and what they spend from their wealth} [Surah An-Nisa: 34]. In this verse, Allah mentioned the reason for placing qawamah (guardianship/authority) in the man - and qawamah is the 'degree' in the previous verse - and that is for two reasons: First: Returning to the origin of creation upon which Allah created humans. text: 36]. It is certain that if man and woman were of one creation and one nature, harmony would not occur between them, and repulsion would occur. Evidence of that is apparent in those whose natures are reversed and concepts corrupted. Second: Spending: which is paying the dowry. Allah created creation with an innate disposition for that, and the Sharia came confirming that the man is the one who pays the dowry to the woman even if she is the richest of people. It is not permissible for a woman to gift herself to anyone without a dowry except the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and that is one of his specific characteristics. 3 - It is known that spending on the wife is upon her husband even if she is rich. The man is more capable of that, and nothing is lost due to his undertaking the earning of sustenance. As for the woman, if she went to earn sustenance, great harm and corruption would occur from her neglect of her function, which is household affairs, raising children, and caring for the husband. The man is capable of things the woman is not capable of, and the woman is capable of things the man is not capable of. By each performing their function, complementarity is achieved and life becomes upright. Unless it is said that the woman performs the man's function and the man performs the woman's function, or one of them performs both functions, which all rational people know is corrupt and causes great harm. 4 - It should be known that the woman's function - which is undertaking household affairs, raising generations, caring for the husband's affairs, and preparing herself for what he needs - is a noble function not less in degree than the man's function, rather it may exceed it, and it suits her creation and nature.

text: Section: Pillars of Marital Coexistence Pillars of marital coexistence. Allah Almighty said: {And live with them in kindness} [Surah An-Nisa: 19]. Marital coexistence rests on three matters: Affection, Mercy, and Upholding the Limits of Allah. Allah Almighty said: {And of His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy} [Surah Ar-Rum: 21]. And He said: {And if he has divorced her [for the third time], then she is not lawful to him afterward until [after] she marries a husband other than him. And if the latter husband divorces her [or dies], there is no blame upon the woman and her former husband for returning to each other if they think that they can keep [within] the limits of Allah. These are the limits of Allah, which He makes clear to a people who know} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 230]. And He said: {And it is not lawful for you to take anything of what you have given them unless both fear that they will not be able to keep [within] the limits of Allah. But if you fear that they will not keep [within] the limits of Allah, then there is no blame upon either of them concerning that by which she ransoms herself. These are the limits of Allah, so do not transgress them. And whoever transgresses the limits of Allah - it is those who are the wrongdoers} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 229]. If these three combine for the couple, they attain worldly happiness, and happiness in the Hereafter is hoped for them. The marriage contract is one of the greatest contracts that must be fulfilled. Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, fulfill [all] contracts} [Surah Al-Ma'idah: 1]. And Allah called it a solemn covenant, saying: {And they have taken from you a solemn covenant} [Surah An-Nisa: 21]. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from the hadith of Uqbah bin Amir

text: - may Allah be pleased with him - that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "The conditions most worthy to be fulfilled are those by which you have made sexual relations lawful." (1) The marriage contract in Islam is a contract of choice, not compulsion. Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him), he said (peace and blessings be upon him): "A previously married woman should not be married until she is consulted, and a virgin should not be married until her permission is sought." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, and how is her permission?" He said: "That she remains silent." (2) Therefore, Allah facilitated the matter of separation between spouses when marital life becomes impossible. If the husband does it [it is divorce], otherwise it is permissible for the woman to ransom herself and there is no blame on her for that. Allah Almighty said: {But if you fear that they will not keep [within] the limits of Allah, then there is no blame upon either of them concerning that by which she ransoms herself} [Surah Al-Baqarah: 229]. Or the Shar'i judge rules for separation between them. But it must be known that this solemn contract cannot be dissolved except by the absence of these three matters which are the pillars of marital coexistence. If affection is absent between them, the bond of mercy and upholding the limits of Allah remains. If mercy is also absent, the bond that each obeys Allah regarding the other remains. It is narrated that a man said to his wife during the time of Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): "I adjure you by Allah, do you love me?" She said: "As for since you adjured me by Allah, then no." He went out until he came to Umar. He sent for her and said: "Are you the one who says to her husband: I do not love you?" She said: "O Commander of the Faithful, he adjured me by Allah, should I lie?" He said: "Yes, lie to him. Not all houses are built on love, but people live together by Islam and lineages (Ahsab)." text: Perhaps when each obeys Allah regarding the other, Allah will reconcile their hearts and affection and mercy will return. For one of the most beloved deeds to Satan is separating spouses due to the corruption and harms resulting from it. Enemies of Islam, when they want to corrupt a country and destroy a nation, plant in it the causes that result in the separation of spouses and consequently the scattering of families and destruction of homes. Muslim narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Iblis places his throne upon the water, then sends his detachments. The closest of them to him in rank is the greatest of them in fitnah (causing trial/corruption). One of them comes and says: 'I did such and such.' He says: 'You have done nothing.' He said: Then one of them comes and says: 'I did not leave him until I separated him and his wife.' He said: So he brings him close to him and says: 'Yes, you [are the one]'." Al-A'mash said: I think he said: "And he embraces him." (1) And Imam Ahmad narrated in his Musnad from the hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Muhammad, two people do not love each other then get separated except due to a sin one of them commits." (2) So if these pillars are absent, then in this case no bond remains to unite them, and separation becomes specific. Allah Almighty said: {But if they separate [by divorce], Allah will enrich each [of them] from His abundance. And ever is Allah Encompassing and Wise} [Surah An-Nisa: 130]. It must be noted that many cases of separation occur based on one spouse evaluating the other with an unjust evaluation in which the person does not adhere to justice and fairness. Therefore, when the cloud of passion clears, he regrets when regret is of no use.

text: The Balance and Justice in Evaluating the Wife: It was previously mentioned in the purposes of marriage the definition of mutual rights and duties between spouses, and that keeping this in mind when evaluating one spouse by the other makes a person just in his judgment and fair to himself. We add clarification here by mentioning some matters that make a man's evaluation of his wife just and correct. Allah Almighty said: {And live with them in kindness. For if you dislike them - perhaps you dislike a thing and Allah makes therein much good} [Surah An-Nisa: 19]. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their Sahihs from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "Treat women well, for they were created from a rib, and the most crooked part of a rib is its upper part. If you go to straighten it, you will break it, and if you leave it, it will remain crooked. So treat women well." (1) And Muslim narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "A believing man should not hate a believing woman. If he dislikes a characteristic in her, he is pleased with another." Or he said: "other than it." (2) From these verses, hadiths, and others, it becomes clear that justice must be observed in evaluating the wife. This is known to every Muslim, but what might be hidden is its application. If a man marries a woman wanting from her all the previously mentioned purposes of marriage: Offspring, Service, and Pleasure, then when wanting to evaluate her, he must look at these three collectively, not each one separately. If he looks at them collectively and

Whereas if he looks at each one separately, he despises that evaluation and judges her as a failure definitely, and the reason is that wrong view. If he kept in mind what the previous verses and hadiths indicated, he would not fall into that error. This is further clarified by the fact that if a man wants only two out of three from the woman, for example, then one-third of the score is not enough to raise the wife's level. Likewise if he wants only one of those purposes. Thus, the difference becomes clear between the woman performing these three purposes and her being asked to perform only some of them. Therefore, when the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) proposed to Umm Salamah, she initially excused herself saying she had children. She meant by offering this excuse - and Allah knows best - that she would be busy with them from fully performing the right of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). And that indeed happened. Muslim narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) sent Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah (may Allah be pleased with him) to propose to me for him. I said: I have a daughter and I am jealous. He said: "As for her daughter, we pray to Allah to suffice her regarding her, and I pray to Allah to remove the jealousy." It is attested by what Imam Ahmad narrated (1) in his Musnad from the hadith of Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her): That when the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) made the contract with her, he used to come to her. He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) came and entered, turning his sight in the house saying: "Where is Zunab (little Zaynab)? What happened to Zunab?" She said: Ammar came and took her. text: Section: Issues of Marital Coexistence One of the issues of marital coexistence where marital life becomes upright by good handling and worsens when not given the required attention is (Maintenance/Nafaqah). We chose it as an example because it occurred in the House of Prophecy and because of what is seen in reality of its effects on the union or separation of spouses, and to be an example to follow in all conditions of marital coexistence. The summary of what happened in the Prophet's house (peace and blessings be upon him) is that his wives increased their demands on him for maintenance until the situation reached the point where they asked him what he did not have. His chest tightened despite his spaciousness, so Allah revealed to him the verse of Choice (Takhyir) and his Lord commanded him to give his wives the choice between being patient with him in straitened living and hardship, or separating from them. This is evidence of the importance of this subject and that it must be given utmost care, as Allah revealed concerning it a Quran recited until the Day of Resurrection. Here are the verses, so ponder: Allah Almighty said: {O Prophet, say to your wives, "If you should desire the worldly life and its adornment, then come, I will provide for you and give you a gracious release. But if you should desire Allah and His Messenger and the home of the Hereafter, then indeed, Allah has prepared for the doers of good among you a great reward."} [Surah Al-Ahzab: 28, 29]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) did what Allah commanded him and gave them the choice one by one. They (may Allah be pleased with them) were of higher status and elevated rank, so they chose Allah, His Messenger, and the Home of the Hereafter.

But if you should desire Allah and His Messenger and the home of the Hereafter, then indeed, Allah has prepared for the doers of good among you a great reward."}" She said: So I said: "Is it about this that I consult my parents? Indeed, I desire Allah, His Messenger, and the Home of the Hereafter." (1) She said: Then the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did the same as I did. In another narration: "No woman among them asks me except I inform her. Indeed, Allah did not send me to be obstinate nor to cause difficulty, but He sent me as a teacher and facilitator." The Amount of Maintenance a Woman Deserves: It is known in Sharia and custom that the husband must spend on his wife regarding housing, clothing, food, and drink. But the wife must know what is due to her from that and what is extra to the obligatory; so she does not ask him what is not obligatory on him as if it is obligatory, such that if he falls short in it she accuses him of negligence and miserliness, and if he does not fall short she does not meet him with the thanks and gratitude he deserves, thinking he only performed his duty. This issue needs elaboration which is not for this place, and we refer to it briefly (2).
